newsitem.title: FRANCE: ATHLETICS-KOFFA SECURES GREEK SPRINT DOUBLE.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-KOFFA SECURES GREEK SPRINT DOUBLE.

text.p: Ekaterina Koffa took a second sprint gold for Greece at the world indoor championships on Saturday at the end of a week in which Athens made the final shortlist of five candidates to stage the 2004 Olympics.
Koffa clocked 22.76 seconds to win the women's 200 metres final by a hundredth of a second from Jamaica's 1992 Olympic silver medallist Juliet Cuthbert.
On the first day of the three-day championships on Friday, Haralambous Papadias won the men's 60 metres title.
Trinidad's Ato Boldon, favourite for the men's 200 title, pulled up suddenly in the final straight and crumpled to the track.
His coach John Smith jumped down from the stands and watched anxiously as Boldon was carried from the track on a stretcher.
The race was won by American Kevin Little in 20.40 seconds.
"It didn't surprise me at all, I felt I could not be beaten,' Little said. "It's nice to have a superstar like Boldon in the race, it certainly takes the pressure off.
Moroccan Hicham el Guerrouj ran away with the men's 1,500 race although his time of three minutes 35.31 seconds was well outside his own world record of 3:31.18 set early last month.
German Ridger Stenzel was well back in second place ahead of Kenya's 1992 Olympic 800 champion William Tanui.
"It was an easy race for me," said el Guerrouj. "I was well prepared and I was not worried.
"I have had a sensational start to this year and I hope there's more to come. This could be my year."
Kazakhstan's Igor Potapovitch won the men's pole vault with a leap of 5.85 metres despite the distractions of the men's long jump competition on the adjacent runway.
Inna Lasovskaya of Russia took the women's triple jump with a leap of 15.01 metres, only two centimetres short of the world record.
"Paris was always my favourite town and Bercy my favourite track," said Lasovakaya.

The women's 3,000 metres, the final track event of the evening, was won in a thrilling sprint finish by Romania's defending champion Gabriela Szabo, who overhauled Irishwoman Sonia O'Sullivan over the final metres.
